questions.text: As per MCI rules, if any request is made for medical records, the documents shall be issued within the period of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 72 hours As per Director General of Health Services (DGHS), Ministry of health and F.W., Govt. of India, • Medical Records of indoor patients is stored in digitised form – indefinitely. • Medical Records in hard copy should be stored as follows: a) OPD Records – 3 years b) In-patient’s Medical Records – 3 years c) Medico-legal Registers and Case Sheets – 10 years or till the disposal of ongoing cases in any of the courts related to these records As per Indian Medical Council (Professional conduct, etiquette and ethics/regulations, 2002) • Indoor patients records should be kept for – 3 years. • A doctor should provide the medical records within 72 hours when the patient or his/her authorised representative makes a request for it.

questions.text: One of the following may not amount to professional misconduct
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Advertisement • Professional Misconduct is any conduct of the doctor, which is considered as disgraceful or dishonourable judged by medical practitioners of good repute and competence. • Dichotomy or fee-splitting, i.e. receiving or giving commission to professional colleague or a manufacturer or trader in drugs or appliances, or to a chemist, dentist etc. • Covering, i.e. having relations with unqualified persons, which enable them to practice midwife, or issuing certificates which enable such practices to occur etc. • Adultery: abuse of professional position by committing adultery or improper conduct with a patient or by maintaining an improper association with a patient. • Advertisement: Can be given on occasions such as, when starting a new clinic, when shifting the clinic etc., but repeated advertisement in a newspaper by a medical practitioner is an example of ethical negligence

questions.text: Loco Parentis is about
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Consent. "Loco parentis" is a legal doctrine that refers to a person or institution acting in the role of a parent and having parental responsibilities, including the ability to give consent on behalf of a child in certain situations. This concept is most often applied in settings such as schools, childcare institutions, or when a guardian temporarily assumes responsibility for a child. For example, a teacher or school administrator may make decisions or provide consent in emergency situations when a parent or legal guardian is not present. The principle of "loco parentis" ensures the well-being and protection of the child by granting temporary decision-making authority to responsible parties. Incorrect Responses: (A) Inheritance: This is incorrect because "loco parentis" does not relate to matters of inheritance or property rights. Inheritance laws govern the distribution of assets after death, which is a separate legal domain unrelated to the temporary assumption of parental responsibilities. (C) Paternity dispute: This is incorrect because "loco parentis" is not about determining biological or legal parentage. Paternity disputes involve legal proceedings to establish the biological father of a child, which is distinct from the concept of acting as a temporary parental figure. (D) Maintenance to the child: This is incorrect because "loco parentis" does not address financial support or child maintenance. Child maintenance pertains to the legal obligation of a parent to provide financial assistance for their child's upbringing, which is a different aspect of family law.

questions.text: Criminal negligence is punishable under which section of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), and what is the maximum term of imprisonment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) has replaced the Indian Penal Code (IPC). The offense previously covered by IPC Section 304A, "Causing death by negligence," is now addressed under Section 106 of the BNS. This section specifically deals with "Causing death by rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide." The BNS has increased the maximum term of imprisonment compared to the IPC. For the general offense of causing death by a rash or negligent act, the punishment can extend to five years. However, a more stringent punishment is prescribed for cases where death is caused by a rash and negligent act while driving a vehicle, in which case the imprisonment can extend to seven years and a fine.

questions.text: Disciplinary control over Registered Medical Practitioners is under
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Explanation: • The doctors are governed by the Medical council of India and state medical council. • If the doctor is guilty of professional misconduct usually the state medical council takes disciplinary action in the form of warning or penal erasure. • The Medical council of India can also take disciplinary action, for example, if the MCI notices that a doctor is given false declaration that he is working as a full time teacher in a medical college, MCI takes action against him. Director of Medical and Health Service, Health secretary of State Government and Indian Medical Association cannot take action against professional misconduct.

questions.text: Criminal negligence is punishable under which section of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), 2023?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) This section pertains to situations where a person causes the death of another through a rash or negligent act that does not amount to culpable homicide. Key Provisions: 1. General Provision: Any individual who causes death by a rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide is punishable with imprisonment for up to five years and is also liable to a fine. 2. Medical Negligence: If such an act is committed by a registered medical practitioner during the performance of a medical procedure, the punishment may extend to two years of imprisonment along with a fine. 3. Hit-and-Run Incidents: In cases where death is caused by rash and negligent driving, and the driver escapes without reporting the incident to the police or a magistrate, the punishment can extend to ten years of imprisonment and a fine.

questions.text: Non voluntary Euthanasia’ means
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Person incapable of making their will • Active Euthanasia: Inflicting painless death by an act of commission e.g. injecting large doses of barbiturates/KCl/curare etc. • Passive Euthanasia: Inflicting painless death by an act of omission e.g. withdrawal of life saving measures/life support. • Voluntary Euthanasia: With the consent of the dying person. • Involuntary (Compulsory) Euthanasia: Without/against the consent of the person. • Non voluntary Euthanasia: The person is incapable of making their wishes known, e.g. irreversibly comatose patient, severely defective patients.

questions.text: Professional secrecy is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Implied term of contract between doctor and patient • Professional secrecy is an implied term of contract between the doctor and his patient. • The doctor is obliged to keep secret, all that he comes to know concerning the patient in the course of his professional work. • Its disclosure would be a failure of trust and confidence. • The patient can sue the doctor for damages if the disclosure is voluntary, has resulted in harm to the patient and is not in the interest of the public.

questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Absence of reasonable care • Professional negligence (Malpractice) is the absence of reasonable care and skill (Act of Commission and/or Act of Omission), or negligence of a doctor in the treatment of a patient, which may result in injury or death. • Just because a doctor diagnose wrongly because of error of judgement and give wrong medicine, it may not amount to negligence. • It is up to the doctor whether to accept or reject a patient, but he should not reject on the grounds of caste, colour, religion, nationality etc.

questions.text: Pari passu means
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Equal in all respects "Pari passu" is a Latin term meaning "equal in all respects." It is often used in legal, financial, and contractual contexts to indicate that two or more parties or things are treated in the same way and have equal standing or rights. For example, in a financial context, creditors may be paid on a pari passu basis, meaning they receive equal treatment or payments in proportion to their claims. The term ensures fairness and equal priority without any party being given preference. Incorrect Responses: (A) Guilty mind: This is incorrect because the term "guilty mind" refers to mens rea, which is a legal concept relating to the mental state of a person at the time of committing a crime. "Pari passu" has no connection to mens rea or the concept of a guilty mind. (B) Necessary changes having been made: This is incorrect as it does not accurately capture the meaning of "pari passu." This phrase refers to equal treatment or standing, not to the idea of changes being made. It does not imply any action or modification, but rather the equal status of entities or actions. (D) Beyond the power: This is incorrect because "parri passu" is not related to exceeding authority or being beyond power. It refers strictly to equality in rights, treatment, or status, not to any kind of overreach or limitation of power. "Pari passu" is widely used to express equality, ensuring fairness and equal treatment across various contexts, especially in legal and financial matters.

questions.text: A doctor should not take fees for issuing the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Death certificate • There are certain specific requirements about death certificates. • If the doctor in attendance is convinced that death is due to any natural cause- a) He must issue a death certificate b) He cannot charge any fees for the same c) He cannot delay it even if his own professional charges are not paid and d) The certificate must state the immediate cause of death like coronary thrombosis instead of a vague term, such as heart failure or cardiac arrest and the underlying cause due to coronary artery disease.

questions.text: A quack injects penicillin after giving test dose. But the patient dies of anaphylactic shock. The quack can defend on the grounds of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) None of the above. In the case described, the quack cannot successfully defend themselves using any of the given options because administering penicillin without proper medical qualifications or protocols is highly negligent. Anaphylactic shock, even after a test dose, indicates a severe allergic reaction that was not anticipated or properly managed. The quack's actions demonstrate a failure to follow medical protocols and safety measures, making it difficult to justify the death under the defenses listed. "None of the above" is the correct answer, as none of these defenses can absolve the quack of liability in this case. Incorrect Responses: (A) Therapeutic misadventure: This is incorrect because "therapeutic misadventure" refers to an unfortunate event that occurs despite proper care and medical procedures, often due to an unforeseen adverse reaction. In this case, however, the quack's failure to follow established medical standards or to properly assess the patient's medical history or risk factors would not qualify as a "misadventure," but rather as medical negligence. (B) Medical maloccurrence: This is incorrect because a "medical maloccurrence" refers to an incident where something goes wrong during treatment, but where the medical professional is acting within their expertise and skill level. Since the individual administering the penicillin is a quack, without the appropriate medical qualifications, this defense cannot apply. (C) Novus actus interveniens: This is incorrect because "novus actus interveniens" refers to a new, intervening act that breaks the chain of causation in a criminal or civil case. In this scenario, the quack’s actions are directly responsible for the patient’s death, and no new act or event intervened to break that chain. Therefore, this defense is not applicable.

questions.text: Doctrine of ‘Res Ipsa Loquitur’ can be applied in case of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Prescription of overdose • Res ipsa loquitor means, the thing speaks for itself. • This doctrine is applied both in civil and criminal negligence. • The legal and procedural effect of the Court’s acceptance of res ipsa loquitar in a negligence action is to shift the burden of proof from the plaintiff (patient) to one of disproof by the defendant (Doctor). • This doctrine cannot be applied against several defendants (i.e. doctors). • To prove Doctrine of Res ipsa loquitar, the following conditions should be satisfied: 1. That in absence of negligence, the injury would not have occurred. 2. Patient has not contributed to negligence. 3. Doctor had exclusive control of the circumstances or injury producing instruments or treatment. E.g.: Amputation of wrong digit or limb, Leaving a swab or instrument in abdomen of patient after operation, Prescription of overdose etc.

choices.text: Don’t vaccinate him as you will be penalized
Obtain a court order and vaccinate him

questions.text: There has been an outbreak of a new strain of virus in your state and Government has made it compulsory that every single person be vaccinated at the earliest so as to check the spread of the disease; but a colleague of yours who is also supposed to be vaccinated, refuses to give consent and says that he will sue you if you vaccinate him without his consent. What is the best option in this scenario?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Obtain a court order and vaccinate him. In this situation, the government has made vaccination compulsory in order to prevent the spread of a new and potentially dangerous virus. Public health laws may prioritize the collective good over individual preferences, especially in the case of contagious diseases. If an individual refuses vaccination, the most legally appropriate course of action would be to seek a court order to compel the vaccination, ensuring that the process is carried out within the legal framework. A court order would provide the necessary legal authority to override the individual’s refusal, while still upholding their rights in a balanced way, and complying with public health directives. Incorrect Responses: (A) Don’t vaccinate him as you will be penalized: This is incorrect because simply not vaccinating the individual could lead to the spread of the disease, which goes against public health requirements. Failing to follow the government's mandate might result in consequences, but the most appropriate response is not to ignore the mandate or avoid action out of fear of penalties. (B) Vaccinate him: This is incorrect because vaccination without consent, in the absence of a legal mandate or court order, can lead to legal consequences such as civil or criminal charges for assault or battery. Even though the situation is urgent, it is important to respect personal rights and the law by seeking proper legal authorization before proceeding. (D) None of the above: This is incorrect because a proper legal course of action exists (option C), which is to seek a court order to ensure the vaccination is administered lawfully, respecting both public health requirements and individual rights.
